Message.Msg: If tegra is not into many China phones, perhaps its bcos of supply constraints at tsmc and not the power efficiency...... Taipei, Aug. 7, 2012 (CENS) -- Nvidia Corp. and MediaTek Inc. are vigorously increasing contracts for Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.'s (TSMC's) 40nm foundry capacity to deal with strong demands for their products. Nvidia has ramped up contracts to TSMC since June this year to cope with strong demands for its Tegra 3 processors from non Apple tablet PC makers. MediaTek has increased contracts to TSMC to handle swarming orders from mainland China's smartphone makers for its MT6575 and MT6577 chips. Strong orders from the two chip vendors have strained TSMC's 40nm foundry capacity, which is estimated not to ease until October this year. Industry executives pointed out that as TSMC has mostly utilized its US$8 billion of capital expenditure for this year to boost 28nm process capacity, tight 40nm foundry supplies have hit the company unexpectedly. They said as major customers such as Qualcomm, Nvidia and AMD have robustly migrated to 28nm process from 40nm node this year, TSMC is not to blame for less investment in 40nm capacity expansion. Nvidia Tegra 3 is currently the only ARM-based quad-core processors for non-Apple tablets, making it popular with big players like Acer, Asustek, LG, Toshiba, and Sony. Even Microsoft Surface and Google Nexus 7 have adopted the processor. Tegra 3 has even begun threatening Qualcomm's 28nm Snapdragon smartphone processors, whose availability are limited by tight 28nm foundry capacity at TSMC. Around 30 smartphone models planned to roll out in the second half this year are estimated to have Tegra 3 inside them

"The Securities and Exchange Commission has filed fraud charges against the former chief financial officer of Nvidia Corp. The SEC's charges against Christine B. Hoberg allege that she intentionally failed to record $3.3 million in expenses relating to a deal with a supplier. As a result of that transaction, Nvidia materially overstated its gross profit and income for the quarter ended April 30, 2000, claims the SEC. Hoberg was charged in a complaint filed in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California. Without admitting or denying the allegations, Hoberg agreed to pay a penalty of nearly $672,000, which includes $597,000 in disgorgement of illegally obtained gains. She also is prohibited from serving as an officer or director of a public company for five years. According to the SEC's complaint, in early 2000 Nvidia was lagging behind expectations for its financial performance for the quarter ended April 30. In order to meet those expectations, Nvidia entered into an agreement with a supplier in which the supplier granted Nvidia $3.3 million in cost reduction credits for the quarter. In exchange, Nvidia agreed to repay the supplier this same amount by paying artificially higher prices on purchases later in the year. Under generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP), Nvidia's explicit agreement to repay the costs to its supplier created a liability that Nvidia was required to record in its accounting records, the SEC noted. Thus, under GAAP, Nvidia should have recorded both the cost reductions and an offsetting liability for its agreement to repay the costs in the future. Instead, explained the SEC, Hoberg directed that Nvidia record only the cost-reduction portion of the transaction on its books for the April 30 quarter. By failing to record the offsetting $3.3 million liability for the second portion of the deal, added the SEC, Hoberg led Nvidia to overstate its gross profit for the quarter by 6.4 percent and its income for the quarter by 15.3 percent. To facilitate the fraud, said the SEC, Hoberg directed that Nvidia document the deal in two separate agreements, one for the cost reductions and another for Nvidia's promise to repay. During a subsequent review of Nvidia's quarterly results by its outside auditors, Hoberg provided the auditors with the first agreement but withheld the second, according to the SEC." .
